title: Please help
content:
Hi.

I really need a font called “Freight Sans”. (NOT for commercial use).

However, I can’t afford the price set forth by the font companies.

Is there a freeware font quite similar to this one?

Thanks a lot.
author: pdm_mdp

comments.content:
Hello PDM,

welcome to Typophile.  
I recommend you reading the 2-epsiode introduction to the [work of a typedesigner](http://web.archive.org/web/20090511044240/http:/www.fontshop.be/details.php?entry=230) by [Yves Peters](http://web.archive.org/web/20090511044240/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Yves%252BPeters), and [The Value of Type](http://web.archive.org/web/20090511044240/http:/www.letterror.com/content/value/index.html) by [Erik van Blokland](http://web.archive.org/web/20090511044240/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Erik%252Bvan%252BBlokland). Furthermore, have a look at the [FAQ Free](http://web.archive.org/web/20090511044240/http:/typophile.com/wiki/FAQ%252BFree).

Microsoft Windows comes with a handsome sans-serif font family by [Joshua Darden](http://web.archive.org/web/20090511044240/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Joshua%252BDarden), the designer of Freight. [Corbel](http://web.archive.org/web/20090511044240/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Corbel) has four weights, very wide language support (including Cyrillic and Greek), small-caps, various figure styles and more. Note that Corbel is [not a free font](http://web.archive.org/web/20090511044240/http:/typophile.com/node/38272).

BTW, here’s a link to [Freight Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20090511044240/http:/www.dardenstudio.com/typefaces/freight_sans).  
F
Jeremy Tankard designed Corbel, not Joshua Darden.

Holy Jeremiah! You’re absolutely right, I messed those two up, sorry.

I still think Corbel could serve as a nice high-quality alternative for the smaller budget.

“really need” = really want.

If you need it, license it. If not, use something else and save up for Freight!
